content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis and preliminary characterisation</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">All chemicals were commercially available and used as received. Crystals of the mixed oxalates ScK(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>I</ce:bold>), InRb<ce:inf loc="post">0.77</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">0.23</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅0.5(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (<ce:bold>II</ce:bold>) and InCs(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>III</ce:bold>) were obtained by soft chemistry routes. The mixed scandium potassium oxalate ScK(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was prepared from a mixture of Sc(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>⋅<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.4 g) and KNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (0.17 g), dissolved in 25 mL of distilled water. A solution of oxalic acid (0.5 mol L<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) was subsequently added in excess until the formation of a white precipitate. The mixture was then heated up to 60 °C and about 10 mL of concentrated HNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> were slowly added until complete dissolution. The evaporation of the solution at room temperature led to the formation of hexagonal-shaped transparent crystals after about twenty hours. Long ago Štěrba-Böhm and Škramovský  prepared mixed oxalates with the suggested formulae ScNH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and ScK(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and reported the hexagonal shape of the monocrystals. The mixed indium rubidium oxalate InRb<ce:inf loc="post">0.77</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">0.23</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅0.5(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) was prepared from the addition of InCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (0.1 g), RbNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (0.13 g) and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>⋅2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.11 g) to 30 mL of distilled water. The fine white precipitate that forms was completely dissolved by heating the mixture at 50 °C under stirring during five minutes. Transparent prismatic crystals appeared at the surface of the solution by slow evaporation at room temperature after about twenty hours. The mixed oxalate InCs(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>III</ce:bold>) has also been prepared in this work. Single crystals were obtained from the slow evaporation of a water solution (25 mL) containing indium chloride (0.1 g), caesium nitrate (0.18 g) and oxalic acid (0.14 g). Transparent prismatic crystals appeared at the surface of the solution by slow evaporation at room temperature after one day. One can notice that Deichman  prepared also mixed indium caesium oxalate and suggested that it is isomorphous to mixed indium and ammonium oxalate by comparison of X-ray photographs.</ce:para>
clean_text:
Experimental

Synthesis and preliminary characterisation

All chemicals were commercially available and used as received. Crystals of the mixed oxalates ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)2 (I), InRb0.77(H3O)0.23(C2O4)2(H2O)2⋅0.5(H2O) (II) and InCs(C2O4)2(H2O)2 (III) were obtained by soft chemistry routes. The mixed scandium potassium oxalate ScK(C2O4)2(H2O)2 was prepared from a mixture of Sc(NO3)3⋅xH2O (0.4 g) and KNO3 (0.17 g), dissolved in 25 mL of distilled water. A solution of oxalic acid (0.5 molL-1) was subsequently added in excess until the formation of a white precipitate. The mixture was then heated up to 60°C and about 10 mL of concentrated HNO3 were slowly added until complete dissolution. The evaporation of the solution at room temperature led to the formation of hexagonal-shaped transparent crystals after about twenty hours. Long ago Štěrba-Böhm and Škramovský  prepared mixed oxalates with the suggested formulae ScNH4(C2O4)2⋅2H2O and ScK(C2O4)2⋅2H2O and reported the hexagonal shape of the monocrystals. The mixed indium rubidium oxalate InRb0.77(H3O)0.23(C2O4)2(H2O)2⋅0.5(H2O) was prepared from the addition of InCl3 (0.1 g), RbNO3 (0.13 g) and H2C2O4⋅2H2O (0.11 g) to 30 mL of distilled water. The fine white precipitate that forms was completely dissolved by heating the mixture at 50°C under stirring during five minutes. Transparent prismatic crystals appeared at the surface of the solution by slow evaporation at room temperature after about twenty hours. The mixed oxalate InCs(C2O4)2(H2O)2 (III) has also been prepared in this work. Single crystals were obtained from the slow evaporation of a water solution (25 mL) containing indium chloride (0.1 g), caesium nitrate (0.18 g) and oxalic acid (0.14 g). Transparent prismatic crystals appeared at the surface of the solution by slow evaporation at room temperature after one day. One can notice that Deichman  prepared also mixed indium caesium oxalate and suggested that it is isomorphous to mixed indium and ammonium oxalate by comparison of X-ray photographs.
